content.body: Not going to argue that.  And does somewhat surprise me
I haven't been in discussions on .at() so I was unaware of the coercion
there were no discussions around coercion specifically at the time, the method follows the coercion precedence of other methods
I wasn't aware it worked with other array methods either, hadn't tried in that in my 24 years of JavaScripting
which is the point of bakkot's proposal. we've been operating on precedence grounds for decades, it's time to rethink that
content.formatted_body: which is the point of bakkot's proposal. we've been operating on precedence grounds for decades, it's time to rethink that

content.body: Strangely enough it works. Had to open a terminal to prove it to myself
yeah.
the thing is that if `array[1.2]` were already valid, then you could argue that `array.at(1.2)` is a non-regression, or something
content.formatted_body: the thing is that if array[1.2] were already valid, then you could argue that array.at(1.2) is a non-regression, or something

content.body: but given that `array[1.2]` is not in fact equivalent to `array[1]`, it definitely seems hard to consider the equivalence of `.at(1.2)` and `.at(1)` a good thing
content.formatted_body: but given that array[1.2] is not in fact equivalent to array[1], it definitely seems hard to consider the equivalence of .at(1.2) and .at(1) a good thing

content.body: `array[1.2]` won't error though, so it's a question of what the behavior should be for `.at()` if we don't want coercion.  There is a sort of coercion happening with `arr[1.2]` as well, and I don't think we would want to extend that to `.at(1.2)`
certainly, `at` isn't meant to string coerece
